chainIssues: Al-Kalbi is classified as Da'if (weak) - a critical weakness in this chain

potential_issues.issue: Multiple transmission paths with varying narrator reliability
potential_issues.impact: Different chains show different levels of reliability - the first chains are relatively stronger with mostly Thiqah narrators, while the Al-Ashja'i chain contains al-Kalbi who is Da'if, significantly weakening that particular transmission path.

potential_issues.issue: Sufyan ibn Uyaynah using 'an in multiple chains
potential_issues.impact: Sufyan is a known mudallis of category 3; his use of 'an (عَنْ) creates ambiguity in whether he directly heard from his sources. However, Sufyan is generally considered reliable by the majority of scholars, so this doesn't severely impact the overall assessment, though it requires noting.

potential_issues.issue: Khalid ibn Sa'd is graded as Saduq/Sadooq
potential_issues.impact: This is below the Thiqah level and present in the earlier chains, which brings down the overall reliability compared to chains with all Thiqah narrators.

potential_issues.issue: Al-Kalbi's weakness in the final chain variant
potential_issues.impact: The variant by Al-Ashja'i contains al-Kalbi (Da'if), making this particular chain unreliable. This version should be treated separately as problematic.

english_translation: Regarding Abdullah ibn Ja'far: He heard Abdullah ibn Ja'far, his son Ja'far narrated from him according to Ibn Uyaynah. Ata'a narrated from Khalid ibn Ubayd ibn Sarah: He heard from Ibn Umar. According to Ruh ibn Ubadah: from Ibn Jurayj, from Ja'far ibn Khalid ibn Sarah, from his father, from Ibn Ja'far, and the first is more authentic.

english_translation: Narrated by Shu'bah from al-Awwam ibn Muzahim: I heard a man from us called Khalid say: I witnessed the conquest of Tustir with Abu Musa, and with us were four women tending the wounded, and Abu Musa gave them shares.

narrators.name: Shu'bah
narrators.full_name: Shu'bah ibn al-Hajjaj ibn al-Ward al-Ataki

chainIssues: Khalid is completely unnamed and unknown (Majhul al-Hal), mentioned only as 'a man from us called Khalid'
This anonymous narrator critically weakens the chain

potential_issues.issue: Unnamed narrator in the chain
potential_issues.impact: The narrator called 'Khalid' is described only as 'a man from us' with no further identification. This is a critical flaw - Majhul al-Hal narrators who are completely unidentified should not be accepted in hadith authentication.

potential_issues.issue: Cannot verify liqa' (meeting) between Al-Awwam and Khalid
potential_issues.impact: While Al-Awwam heard from this unnamed Khalid, there is no documentation of their meeting or the time period in which they transmitted, making verification of direct transmission impossible.

IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Incident of the conquest of Tustir with Abu Musa
Women tending to the wounded in battles
Distribution of war spoils to women

english_translation: An employee of Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz said from Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz, and Irak (mursal): Different narrators transmitted from him including Khalid al-Hadda', Mubarak ibn Fadala, and Wasil freed slave of Abi Uyanah. Musa narrated to us from Hammad from Khalid al-Hadda' from Khalid ibn Abi al-Salt: We were near Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz, then Irak ibn Malik said: I heard from Aisha that the Prophet ﷺ said: "Turn my sitting place to the Qibla" with his private parts. Musa also said: Uhaib narrated to us from Khalid from a man that Irak narrated from Umrah from Aisha from the Prophet ﷺ. Ibn Bakir said: Bakr narrated to me from Ja'far ibn Rabi'ah from Irak from Urwah that Aisha used to deny their saying: "Do not face the Qibla," and this is more authentic.

english_translation: He was in Wasit, then killed in Kufa near the year one hundred and twenty, from his father, from his grandfather. Syar Abu al-Hakam narrated from him. He is the one who said on the day of al-Adha (the Feast of Sacrifice): "I will sacrifice with al-Ja'd ibn Dirham, who claimed that Allah did not speak to Musa with direct speech, and did not take Ibrahim as a friend." Then he came down and slaughtered him. According to Qubayt: We are told by al-Qasim ibn Muhammad from Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Habib ibn Abi Habib, from his father, from his grandfather, saying: I witnessed Khalid and he is the brother of Asad. We were told by Abdullah, who said: We were told by al-Layth, who said: We were told by Yahya ibn Said: There was a man from the people of al-Jazira who was a governor over us as a deputy of al-Qasri, and he was a truthful man. He is Yazid ibn Asad ibn Karza Abu al-Haytham.

chainIssues: Biographical entry describing death and genealogy

potential_issues.issue: Complex, multi-generational transmission through family lines
potential_issues.impact: The transmission through 'from his father, from his grandfather' involves multiple generations without clear identification of all narrators.

english_translation: A biographical entry regarding Khalid ibn Abdullah ibn Asid

narrators.name: Khalid ibn Abdullah
narrators.full_name: Khalid ibn Abdullah ibn Asid al-Qurashi

potential_issues.issue: Khalid ibn Abdullah ibn Asid is graded as Saduq, not Thiqah
potential_issues.impact: While generally reliable, this narrator is below the highest standard of reliability.

Topics: Biographical information on Khalid ibn Abdullah ibn Asid

english_translation: He heard from Qubayt ibn Dhu'ayb from Zayd ibn Thabit: "When she becomes pure from the third menstrual period, she becomes lawful." Ahmad said this, from his father. He heard from Ibrahim from Muhammad ibn Masrara from al-Zuhri. Bishr said: from his father from al-Zuhri, who informed me: Khalid ibn Abdullah ibn Khalid ibn Asid told me the same. He is the brother of Umayah and Musa.

narrators.name: Zayd ibn Thabit
narrators.full_name: Zayd ibn Thabit ibn al-Dahhak al-Ansari

narrators.name: Al-Zuhri

chainIssues: Multiple narrators at Saduq level (Bishr, al-Mufaddal, Khalid)
Al-Zuhri is reported with using 'an (عَنْ) with a mudallis, though he is reliable

potential_issues.issue: Unidentified narrators Ahmad and his father
potential_issues.impact: The second chain contains completely unidentified narrators, making it unreliable.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple narrators at Saduq level
potential_issues.impact: Qubayt ibn Dhu'ayb, Muhammad ibn Masrara, Bishr, al-Mufaddal, and Khalid ibn Abdullah are all Saduq level, below Thiqah.

potential_issues.issue: Al-Zuhri using 'an despite being a mudallis
potential_issues.impact: While al-Zuhri is generally considered reliable, his mudallis status requires careful evaluation with indirect transmission terms like 'an.
